With this purpose in mind, she is requesting a loan in the amount of $600 for a term of 6 months. With your help, Nigora feels that her business will continue to succeed and that, in turn, she will be able to cover all the expenses of her kids as they grow older. She is grateful to everyone for their support.

loans.use: To expand and diversify her business' product line by purchasing modern styles of clothing (e.g., the national dresses, trousers, and “Sherozi”) for women.

loans.name: Chum

texts.en:
Mrs. Chum C., 30, is a mother of two children and lives in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She works selling groceries in front of her house. Normally, she makes $2 of profit per day. Her husband, Meas Keo, is a construction foreman. He works constructing houses in his town. This couple has two children. One of them is a student and another one is not yet school aged.

Mrs. Chum C. has applied for a loan from KIVA to expand her grocery inventory and the leftovers will be used to purchase a motor-bike for her husband to commute to work. The motor-taxi cost is very expensive as the inflation rate in Cambodia is very high and everything is extremely expansive, including gasoline. She and her husband believe that the new motor-bike will reduce their transportation costs and make their family more comfortable.

loans.use: Expand grocery inventory, and purchase a motor-bike for her husband to commute to work.

loans.name: Muhayo

texts.en:
Muhayo I. is 28 years old. She is a widow and she has two children. Muhayo has received very little assistance in helping to raise her kids, so for the past 5 years she has been sewing dresses (e.g., the Tajikistan national dresses) for women because she feels that doing so is the only way to earn enough money to ensure a bright future for her kids. Muhayo works at home, where she takes orders and then fills the orders by sewing dresses to meet her customers' requests. Over these past five years, she has gained invaluable experience in the tailoring business. Muhayo specializes in sewing clothing for women, in both European styles and the national style of Tajikistan.

She is now requesting a loan in the amount of $600, which she will repay over 6 months, in order to purchase a new sewing machine to enable her to provide an even better tailoring service and to thereby make her business more profitable. Muhayo is counting on your help because, with your help, she will be able to expand and improve her business.

loans.use: To expand and improve her business by purchasing a new sewing machine

loans.name: Teo Mbatudde's Group

texts.en:
Teo M. is a tailor who enjoys wearing her designs. She is a married woman with 6 children, the youngest being 6 and the oldest 18, all of whom are in school. Teo has been operating her shop for 7 years and finds business to be fair.

In order to make clothes for both men and women, Teo rides a matatu (a shared van) into Kampala to buy textiles and then returns to the store she rents to do the tailoring. She serves an average of 5 customers a day and with the revenues from the tailor shop has been able to open a bar in which she sells beer and soda.

Teo got her first loan from MCDT 4 years ago and has successfully paid back 8 loans. By working with MCDT, she has been able to sell more clothes because she can get more materials to serve more customers. In addition, she has expanded to making uniforms for a local elementary school, The Red Star School. This success has not come without difficulties, as some people do not pay on time for the clothes she has made or sometimes do not pay at all, making it difficult to predict and rely on a steady cash flow.

Due to the proceeds she has garnered thus far, Teo has been able to sustain her family and send all her children to school. With this loan, she hopes to get a step closer to her future goals of expanding her businesses and buying a new plot of land for her house.

The other members of the group are Ruth N., who sells old clothes; Hamida N., who owns and runs a salon; Robina Nabosa, who sells charcoal; and Miriam M., who sells raw food.

loans.use: To stock more materials to make clothes

loans.name: Dy

texts.en: Mrs. Dy S., 42, earns around $5 per day by making rice wine and raising pigs, Her husband, Mr.Houn Hoeurn, 46, is a soldier. They live in Khvean Village, Siem Reap Province and have four children. One of their children is working for a shopping center and is earning around $50 per month. Because of their family’s growing expenses and because they would like to improve their income, Mrs. Dy S. is seeking a loan of $1200 to purchase a motorcycle for family use. She plans to use remainder of the loan to purchase pig food for her pig-raising business. The loan will help to reduce the family’s expenses so it will improve their living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle to use in family and she plan to use remainder of loan purchase pig food for her pig raising business

loans.name: Duch

texts.en:
Duch K. H. is 36 years old, and since 2000 she has sold groceries in her village. There are not many sellers who sell the same products as she does, so her stall is one of the main suppliers in the village. On average, she makes $7.50 in revenue each day. Her husband is a wedding chef and per day he can earn $3.30. This couple has five dependents. Three are her children who are at school, plus their mother and their brother.

To meet customer demand, which is increasing every day, she would like to take out a loan from Kiva to purchase more groceries to sell. (This picture was taken at one of CREDIT's offices.)

loans.use: To buy more groceries to increase inventory.

loans.name: Phen

texts.en: Phen R., age 44, is a widow and lives with her children in Phnom Penh. She has a business renting rooms to the garment workers, typically earning around $7 each day. She has a few rooms and the rent ranges from US$25 up to US$45 each month. Phen has five children, one of whom is married and no longer lives with her. To contribute to the family's daily income, Phen is supported by her daughter name Duk Keo Lina, who works in a restaurant, and makes around $5 per day. Phen still has two nieces who are under her care as well. To rent more rooms to the garment workers, she would like a loan to build more rooms. ( Mrs. Phen is pictured inside her house.)

loans.use: To build rooms to rent.

loans.name: Sok

texts.en: Sok I. is married and lives with her husband in the outskirts of Phnom Penh. She has two children, who are students. Sok and her husband are farmers, normally earning around $4 each day. Recently the weather conditions have not been good, so the family has found it difficult to farm. To improve their standard of living, they plan to take out a loan to raise animals and purchase rice to make rice wine. These two businesses present a good opportunity that will lead to an improvement in their standard of living. Farmers like raising animals because it is easy to get income and spend less. Moreover, rice wine is very popular among Cambodia farmers. They like to drink rice wine because it cheap and not harmful to their health.

loans.use: To raise animals and purchase rice to make rice wine.

loans.name: Tep

texts.en:
Tep M., 51, is married and lives with her husband in Phnom Penh. She owns a plot of land where she grows rice, eventually making around $3 each day. Her husband, Pum Serei, 46, earns on average about $4, from carpentry. This couple has three children, two of whom are students.

Now, Tep would like a loan from Kiva to purchase rice seed and fertilizers. The leftover will be used to buy carpentry tools. (Mrs. Tep is pictured with her husband at home.)

loans.use: To purchase rice seed, fertilizers, and carpentry tools.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Nang

texts.en:
Nang S., 50, is a mother of seven children and lives in Phnom Penh. She is a farmer, typically earning around $3 each day. Her husband, Ouch Pov, is a construction worker who builds houses and make $4 profit every day. Three of their children are married and no longer live with the family, one is construction worker the same as the father, and one more daughter works at the farm.

Mr. Ouch now would like a loan from Kiva to purchase a motorbike to commute to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to commute to work.

loans.name: Bun

texts.en: Bun S., age 44, is married and lives with her five children in Phnom Penh. She has a business of selling a kind of Khmer cake called “Ta Pea” at the local market. This kind of cake is made with sticky rice. Her husband Phoeun, 41, earns $3 each day from farming. Two of their children are garment workers and the rest are students. Now Bun would like to loan from Kiva to purchase sticky rice in bulk to make the cakes and sell at the market in large quantities.

loans.use: To purchase sticky rice in bulk.

loans.name: Ann

texts.en: Ann S. O., 35, has owned a small stand since 2006, where she sells various kinds of stuff like shoes, light torches, ingredients, soft drinks, beer, and other household products for customers. On average, she makes $7.50 in revenue. Her husband, Hoeun Hon, has a big ice store in the village where he sells ice to the community, and earns about $6.50 each day. In Cambodia, most of the people buy ice from the ice store or ice vendor daily. They put ice into their clean water for their daily drink, and unlike the people in the city, they have their own refrigerator. Mrs. Ann S. O. would like to expand her inventory to meet her growing customer demand, as well as to generate more additional income.

loans.use: To expand her grocery inventory

loans.name: Kak

texts.en: Kak L., 44, is married and lives with her husband in Phnom Penh. She works selling fish in a busy market near her house, and makes on average $4/day. Her husband is a farmer and makes less than one dollar every day. This couple has two children, one of whom is employed as a garment worker and the other one helps doing the housework. Kak would like a loan from Kiva for her husband to purchase more land to grow rice.

loans.use: To purchase more land to grow rice.

loans.name: Madena Makula's Group

texts.en:
Madena is the leader of 4 members. She is 30 years old and married with 1 child. Her child is 15 years old and attends school. The community she lives and works in is urban and is a slum within a low-lying area that floods in the rainy season.

Madena has been operating a hair salon in order to generate income since 1997. The market for her business is fair, and her main challenge is paying electricity bills and rent.

Madena plans on using this loan to buy hair products and braids. She has successfully paid back 8 loans, and in doing so has been able to feed her family, pay rent, and educate her child. In addition, she has been able to modernize her salon. Madena’s future plans include buying a plot to one day build a house.

loans.use: To buy hair products and braids

loans.name: Prem

texts.en: Prem S., 55, is a good housewife who stays at home to look after the children and cook food for the whole family. Her husband is the head of the family and works as a motor-taxi driver. He normally stations himself around the hotel, and his regular customers are foreigners who visit Cambodia. On average, he makes $9 each day. This couple has three children and all of them are married. There is only one child who still lives with the parents. They have some free land, so they want to build some rooms to rent to the garment workers. This will help the family earn an extra income. (Prem's husband is pictured with his motorcycle.)

loans.use: Build rooms to rent.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Um

texts.en: Mrs. Um S., 48, and her husband live in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. They have 3 children, and one of them is a garment worker. Um has been working on her rice field since 1979 and her average profit is less than $1 each day. Her husband has been a construction foreman for over ten years. He does construction work sometimes outside the village, depending on where he gets the construction job. To make an additional income, this couple would like to take out a loan from Kiva to open a food stand to sell food in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. The leftover funds will be used to buy a water pump in case they have a problem with water supply.

loans.use: To open a stall for her children to sell rice and food in Phnom Penh to generate additional profits.

loans.name: Kem

texts.en: Kem T., age 53, is a widow and lives with her five children in Phnom Penh. She makes approximately $2.50 each day, making Khmer cakes. Four children are married and no longer live at home; the last child is a garment worker. Now Kem would like a loan of $200 to purchase more rice to make Khmer cakes. This is a good way to increase the amount of cakes to sell.

loans.use: To purchase rice to make Khmer cakes.

loans.name: Esther Kyeswa's Group

texts.en:
Esther is the leader of 4 members. She is 28 years old and married with 3 children. Her children are 2, 5, and 12 years old and all attend school. The community she lives and works in is urban and is a slum within a low-lying area that floods in the rainy season.

Esther sews sponges at home and has been in business for 4 years. She sells her sponges to others who have booths at shops and markets in Kampala. The market for her business is large, and her main challenges are the high costs of materials and the lack of enough water during the dry season.

Esther plans on using this loan to buy additional raw materials for her business, pay her children’s school fees, and provide food for her family. She has successfully paid back 10 loans and in doing so has been able expand her business. In addition, she hopes to one day fulfill her dream of buying a plot of land where she could eventually build a house.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials for her business

loans.name: Chey

texts.en: Chey C., age 35, is a motor-taxi driver. Living in Phnom Penh, he typically makes $3/day and his wife stays at home to look after the children and cook food for the family. Now this couple wants to grow some vegetables for additional income to support the family. They would like to request a loan of US$200 from Kiva to purchase good seed to grow. (Mr. Chey is pictured at home.)

loans.use: To purchase good rice seed.

loans.name: Ou

texts.en: Ou S. lives in Russey Keo with his wife and five children, and works as a fisherman. He typically makes US$1.50 each day and his wife, Chhub Kim Lang, works to collect recycling materials, making US$4 every day. The family is also supported by the work of one son who is in the construction business. Inflation has been very high in Cambodia over the past year and it has affected food prices and the costs of other basic necessities. Ou has approached CREDIT for a loan of US$1000 to purchase some recycling materials in bulk to resell. The family sees this as an investment and an opportunity that can increase the family’s income and improve their standard of living.

loans.use: Purchase recycling materials

loans.name: Chao

texts.en: Chao R., age 72, is an old mother and has four children. All the children are married and live away from home. Only one grandchild lives with her and works as a construction worker. Chao owns a plot of farmland growing rice. She makes $1 per day. To earn extra income Chao would like to loan from Kiva to purchase a motorbike for her grandchild to operate as a motor taxi whenever he is free from the construction work. (She is pictured with two grandchildren)

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her grandchild to operate when he is free from his job

loans.name: Seng

texts.en: Seng O., 51, is a widow living in Russey Keo where she sells vegetables, pork, and beef. She typically makes $4.50 at the food market and is supported by her three children who work in garment factories and in construction. Seng O. has seen an opportunity to expand her business through the purchase of a stall in the market for her goods. She believes that this stall will give her better access to customers and the ability to increase her daily profits. She has asked for a loan of $1000 to purchase this stall in the market. She does not want to stop there, though, and in the future, she hopes to expand her business even further. She would like to own her own shop some day, selling rice as well as her other foods.

loans.use: Purchase a stall in the market

loans.name: Beuk

texts.en: Beuk L. K. is a mother of six children and with her husband is a farmer growing rice and vegetables. On average, they make $4 each day. In the past year, the weather conditions have been difficult in Cambodia and inflation has been out of control. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Beuk included. She has six children, three of whom are married and no longer live at home. Beuk L. K. would like a loan of $1000 to purchase a cow to plow the land and good rice seed to grow next season. (Mrs. Beuk is pictured at her farmland.)

loans.use: To purchase a cow and rice seed.

loans.name: Chhun

texts.en: Chhun V. is a 28-year-old widow who lives in Phnom Penh, Cambodia with her child. Since 2005 she has been running a small shop selling rice and coffee. She also lives with her sister, Chhun Tola, who handles renting out rooms from their home to workers who live in the area. V. is requesting a loan of $1000 in order to invest $300 into her rice business and to put $700 towards the construction of additional rooms onto her house so that she can expand her room rental business.

loans.use: To invest more into her rice business and to finance construction of adding rooms to her house to rent out

loans.name: Kat

texts.en: Kat T., 29, is a tractor driver who lives in Russey Keo with his wife (pictured above) and two young children. He typically makes $4 every day as a tractor driver, while his wife makes $2.50 as a garment factory worker. Kat T. has asked for a loan of $1000 to purchase a small tractor. The farming industry is very difficult, and farmers do not always have access to a cow or tractor to plow their lands. Kat T. would rent out his tractor to these farmers and make a profit on his purchase. He sees an opportunity in his area for this type of business and believes it can really help his family. In the future, he would like to be able to help his wife open up a grocery store.

loans.use: Purchase small tractor

loans.name: Mann

texts.en: Mann S. O., age 33, has business selling vegetables in a local market. She typically makes $3 each day. Her husband, NO. Sophal, works at the construction site and earns approximately $3 a day. This couple has two children who are students. They want a loan to raise animals for an extra income to support the family. (Mrs. Mann is pictured with her husband at home.)

loans.use: To raise animals.

loans.name: Touch

texts.en: Touch S. lives in Russey Keo with his wife and three young children. He is a construction worker who makes $7 each day, while his wife, Leng Pou, makes $2.50 as a tailor. Touch S. must support two of his children who attend the local school and the other child who is still too young to attend school. During this time of high inflation and high food costs in Cambodia, he has determined a few ways in which he can cut down on expenses and increase his daily income. He has asked for a loan of $500 to purchase a motorbike. The purchase of a motorbike will cut down on his public transportation costs, and it will also allow him to run motortaxi service at times. He has an entrepreneurial mindset and would like to see his family taken care of, along with his standard of living improved.

loans.use: Purchase motorbike

loans.name: Tem

texts.en: Tem S., age 36, is married and lives with her husband in an outskirt area. She has business selling vegetables in a local market. On average, she earns around $2 each day. Her husband, Eal Kun, makes around $3 from his motor-taxi business. They have seven children, two of whom are employed by a garment factory. Mrs. Tem S. would like a loan of $700 to purchase a cow for reselling and to increase the number she's selling to meet her customer demand. (Tem and her husband are pictured with the children)

loans.use: To purchase cows and increase the number sold.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more pigs and pigs feed

loans.name: Sout

texts.en: Sout S., 51, lives in Russey Keo with his wife, Kim Seoung (pictured above), and they have three children who are married and working on their own. He is a blacksmith who typically makes $4 everyday, while his wife makes the same amount as a tailor. Their children work as a motortaxi driver, a farmer, and one is also in the tailoring business. Sout S. would like to see his family’s income increased, and he has asked for a loan of $1200 to accomplish this purpose. With the $1200 Sout S. would like to expand his wife’s tailoring business through the purchase of more cloth to make more clothes. He would also like to purchase a new motorbike to help his son’s motortaxi service. Their current motorbike is old and unreliable, so it has detracted from his business.

loans.use: Purchase cloth; Replace motorbike

loans.name: Aisha Namanda's Group

texts.en:
Aisha is the leader of 5 members. She is 35 years old and married with 3 children. Her children are 6, 10, and 13 years old and all attend school. The community she lives and works in is urban and is a slum within a low-lying area that floods in the rainy season.

Aisha has been selling shoes for 3 years in the village of Kazo. The market for her business is fair, and her main challenge is earning enough money when she doesn’t have enough customers.

Aisha plans on using this loan to pay her children’s school fees and invest in more shoes to sell. She has successfully paid back 4 loans and in doing so has been able to feed her family and educate her children. In addition, she hopes to one day fulfill her dream of buying a plot of land where she could eventually build a house.

loans.use: To buy more shoes to sell

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Micro Credit Development Trust SACCO (MCDT) - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Long

texts.en: Long N., 34, is married and lives with one of her child in Phnom Penh. She lives in the outskirts and works growing a variety of vegetables. She always takes the crops and sells them to market to earn approximately $3 each day. Her husband is a dealer, purchasing motorbikes and reselling. To reduce the expense that Mrs. Long spends on the motor-taxi to bring the crops to sell in the market, now she is asking for a loan from Kiva to purchase a motorbike and the remaining would be used to buy vegetable seeds to grow for the next season. (Mrs. Long's husband is pictured alone.)

loans.use: To purchase motorbike and vegetable seeds.

loans.name: Thi Xuan's Group

texts.vi:
Mrs. Đàm Thị Xuân (Ms 070028), 38 years old, would like to take out a loan to invest in her small grocery store. She is regarded as trustworthy woman by villagers. Her husband is a carpenter. The income is about 2,500,000 VND a month is used to household expense and loan payments. Her group has 5 other members. They all apply for loans of the same amount of 3,808,000 VND except Nguyễn Thị Hà for 3,360,000 VND.
  • Nguyễn Thị Hà (Ms 070028), 31 years old, applies for a loan to expand her factory.
  • Nguyễn Thị Mắn (Ms 070026), 54 years old, applies for a loan to invest in her small business.
  • Hoàng Thị Miên (Ms 070003), 38 years old, applies for a loan to invest in her refreshment stand.
  • Phạm Thị Thanh Thu (Ms 070024), 38 years old, applies for a loan to buy an industrial grade sewing machine.
  • Nguyễn Thị Vân (Ms 070031), 37 years old, applies for a loan to invest in her fish selling business.

Translated from Vietnamese by ngungo, Kiva volunteer.


Chị Đàm Thị Xuân 38 tuổi(Ms 070028), mức vay 4.256.000 vnđ để đầu tư buôn bán nhỏ. Gia đình chị có một cửa hàng nhỏ phục vụ những người dân trong làng.Chị là người có uy tín và được mọi người yêu mến.Chồng chị làm thợ mộc, hai con chị còn nhỏ.Thu nhập từ bán hàng chị tiết kiệm trang trải cuộc sống, một phần trả vốn dần.Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 2.500.000 vnđtháng. Trong nhóm chị còn có: Nguyễn Thị Hà 31 tuổi (Ms 070028),mức vay 3.360.000 vnđ.Chị vay vốn đầu tư mở rộng nhà xưởng Nguyễn Thị Mắn 54 tuổi (Ms 070026), mức vay 3.808.000 vnđ.Chị vay vốn đầu tư buôn bán nhỏ. Hoàng Thị Miên 38 tuổi (Ms 070003) , mức vay 3.808.000 vnđ.Chị vay vốn đầu tư bán hàng giải khát. Chị Phạm Thị Thanh Thu 38 tuổi (Ms 070024), mức vay 3.808.000 vnđ.Với khoản vốn vay này, chị mua máy khâu công nghiệp làm may tại nhà. Nguyễn Thị Vân 37 tuổi (Ms 070031), mức vay 3.808.000 vnđ để đầu tư buôn bán cá.

loans.use: various small businesses

loans.name: Tet

texts.en: Tet N. lives in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, and helps to support her family by running an apartment rental business out of her home, renting additional bedrooms to garment workers. She is applying for a loan of $1,200 in order to renovate her house to better increase her rental business. Mrs. Tet has two children, one of whom is married and contributes to the family income through pickle sales. The other child is a student at a local school. Mrs. Tet is pictured here with her daughter. She is a client of CREDIT MFI, a Cambodian Microfinance company that is a division of the international NGO World Relief.

loans.use: To renovate her house for rental purposes

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Ngan

texts.en: Ngan C., 47, lives in Sa Ang with her husband (pictured above) and two children. She works in a grocery store close to her home, making $5 each day, while her husband helps to support the family through his motortaxi service. Their children are also able to help support the family, as one of their sons is also a motortaxi driver and their daughter helps to sell the groceries. The drawback of the family’s motortaxi business, though, is that they only have one motorbike and so both the son and father cannot both earn money at the same time. Ngan C. has asked for a loan of $1200 to purchase another motorbike for her son to run his own taxi service. She would also like to see her grocery store expanded with any of the leftover money. She sees an opportunity in her area to expand her business and would like to see her income grow.

loans.use: Purchase groceries; Purchase motorbike

loans.name: Robinah Nandyose's Group

texts.en:
Robinah is the leader of 4 members. She is 32 years old and single with 3 children. Her children are 9, 15, and 17 years old and all attend school. The community she lives and works in is urban and is a slum within a low-lying area that floods in the rainy season.

Robinah has been operating a hotel and selling food for the past 7 years. The market for her business is fair, and her main challenge is paying the high rent while also ensuring she has enough money to pay her children’s school fees.

Robinah plans on using this loan to pay her children’s school fees and invest more into her business. She has successfully paid back 7 loans and in doing so has been able to feed her family and educate her children. In addition, she has been able to buy a plot of land where she hopes to one day fulfill her dream of building a house.

loans.use: To further invest in her business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Micro Credit Development Trust SACCO (MCDT) - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Pheng

texts.en: Pheng C., age 52, is a mother of seven children and works selling fish in a busy market. She earns approximately $4 per day. Her husband owns a plot of farmland, and he's been planting a variety of vegetables and rice since 1990. Three of the children are married and live away from home; two are employed and the other help with the father’s work. Now because of the difficulty of a dry season, Mrs. Pheng’s husband would like to purchase a water pump to irrigate the crops. The leftover will be used to increase the number of fish to resell for additional profit.  (Her husband is pictured because Mrs. Pheng C. was not available)

loans.use: To purchase a water pump to irrigate their crops in a dry season

loans.name: Chin

texts.en: Chin S., age 48, is a mother of three children and lives with her husband in Phnom Penh. Since 2003 she has worked planting vegetables and selling them to the market. On average, she makes $3 per day. Her husband, S. Manch, is a farmer, too. One of their children is a garment worker and receives $75 each a month. This couple would like to loan from Kiva to purchase vegetable seed to grow for the next season. (Mrs. Chin is pictured at the farm.)

loans.use: To raise animals.

loans.name: Annet Namayanja's Group

texts.en:
Annet is the leader of 4 members. She is 54 years old and divorced with 5 children. The children are 33, 28, 25, 23, and 19 years old. The youngest child is in school, while the 4 older children are past school age. The community she lives and works in is urban and is a slum within a low-lying area that floods in the rainy season.

Annet goes to the village to purchase and cut down maize and matoke (green, non-sweet bananas that are a main part of the diet in Uganda). She then roasts the maize and sells that and the matoke on the roadside. Her customers purchase small quantities, with the exception of a few who buy from her to sell to others.

Her main challenge is that she cannot work when it rains because she sells her goods at the side of the road rather than in a shop.

Annet plans to use this loan to buy more maize, as it is currently in season. Thus far, her loans have helped her pay school fees and feed her family. In addition, she has been able to buy a plot on which she hopes to one day build a house for her family.

Annet has successfully paid back 15 loans.

loans.use: To buy more maize

loans.name: Chhea

texts.en: Chhea S. L. is a widow who lives in Sa Ang where she sells porridge and rice. She typically makes $4 each day in the market and is also supported by her daughter who works in the garment factory. Inflation has been very high in Cambodia over the past year and it has affected food prices and the costs of other basic necessities. Many Cambodians are struggling to pay these higher prices and have turned to microloans to help them improve their circumstances. Chhea S. L. has asked for a loan of $400 to invest in her rice business. The price of rice has risen rapidly, and she sees this investment as a good way to increase her daily income. She would also like to use some of the money to purchase some land to fill the business site during the rainy season. During the rainy season there are many floods, and she understands that she needs to be very careful with her rice crop.

loans.use: Invest in rice business; Purchase land to fill business site

loans.name: Pov

texts.en: Mr. Pov C. is 41 and lives in the outskirts of Phnom Penh and has worked as a door-to-door repair technician since 1980. His wife (pictured here) is 43 and is a housewife. Together they have one child. Mr. Pov is requesting a loan for $1,000. He would like to purchase wood and renovate his house. After renovation, he hopes he can rent out some of his rooms to nearby factory workers as housing. There are many workers in the area who come from the provinces seeking work in Phnom Penh City.  Eventually, when their financial situation is more stable, Mr. and Mrs. Pov would like to raise animals.  Mr. Pov is a client of CREDIT MFI, a Cambodian microfinance institution that is a part of the international NGO World Relief.

loans.use: Home renovation for the purpose of room rentals

loans.name: Sorry For Me Group

texts.en:
Aminata K. is the leader of the "Sorry for Me" Group. She is 45 years old and is married with 3 children. The members originated from a rotating savings club. The group pulled their savings together and helped each other with loans to start small businesses but they had insufficient capital to enable them to make a good profit.

With the advent of SMT, the solidarity group joined the program. The group is very happy that, since then, their profit increased and most of them were able to pay their children's school requirements and have two meals a day. With unemployed husbands, the members' businesses are the main source of income for the family. Aminata, the leader, and Mamusu sell rice, beans and peanuts. Isatu S. sells local food made out of cassava flour, and Isatu L. sells dishes in the market of Magburaka. The group is therefore requesting a loan of SLL 2,800,000 to increase their stock and earn more income for their families.

loans.use: To purchase food stuffs and home utensils to increase stock and income

loans.name: Khoun

texts.en: Mrs. Khuon C. lives in the outskirts of Phnom Penh with her husband. Together they have three children, and Mrs. Khuon works as a housewife to care for them. Her husband works as a motortaxi driver, and the family has been saving money in order to replace his old motorbike with a newer and better functioning one. They are applying for this loan to meet the remainder of the money they will need to purchase this new motorbike. In the future, Mrs. Khuon hopes to open and run her own clothing store.

loans.use: To purchase a new motorbike for her husband, a motortaxi driver

loans.name: Chan

texts.en: Chan N. is 52 years old and has been working as a grocer since 1998. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver, transporting passengers from place to place in his town. There are only a few grocery stores in her community and her store is the biggest compared to the others. She can typically make on average around $5 per day of income, while her husband makes around $2.50 per day from a motor-taxi. Chan N. has four children. One is single and is a student and the rest are married and stay outside the family’s home. Recently, Mrs. Chan N. requested a loan from KIVA to purchase more groceries to keep expanding her inventory as well as to meet her customer demand.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to expand her inventory

loans.name: Luk

texts.en: Luk K., 54, is a widow who lives in Sa Ang with three of her children. She is supported by two of her children who work in a garment factory and as a waiter in a local restaurant. Inflation has been very high in Cambodia over the past year, and it has affected food prices and the costs of other basic necessities. Luk K. has turned to CREDIT for a loan of $800 to help her family increase their income and improve their standard of living. With the loan, she would like to purchase a motorbike for her children to ride to work, and with any leftover money, she would like to renovate her home. Public transportation costs have risen alongside gas prices, and this purchase would cut down on needless expenses. Her home is also in need of repair, and the loan can provide enough money to meet both of these needs.

loans.use: Purchase motorbike; Renovate house

loans.name: Chea

texts.en:
Chea S., 37, has a small store at the local market selling fish. She receives her product from her husband who is a fisherman. On average, she makes $2 each day. Sometimes her husband, Bai Chuon, catches fewer fish because he does not have enough fishing tools. To help with their business, Mrs. Chea would like to take out a loan to purchase more fishing tools for her husband to use. She thinks this investment will improve his catches and help to stabilize their income.

Mrs. Chea was not available when we visited. Her husband is pictured here working on some of the tools he uses to catch fish.

CREDIT MFI is an independent Cambodian faith-based organization. It aims to empower the economically active poor and small entrepreneurs by providing inclusive financial services throughout both rural and urban communities in Cambodia.

loans.use: To purchase fishing tools.

loans.name: Hiung

texts.en: Mrs. Hiung K. is 46 years old and a housewife in Phnom Penh Cambodia. Her husband, Mr. Keut Om, is 44 and is currently unemployed. The couple has five children, one of whom is married. Three of the children help to support their family by working in garment factories, earning up to $70 US per month each. Mrs. Hiung is applying for a loan to add to her family's savings and to purchase a motorbike to help her husband start a motortaxi business. In the future, she would like to open and run her own grocery store.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to run a motortaxi business.

loans.name: Keo

texts.en: Keo C., 40, lives in Sa Ang with his wife, Keo Srey Puch (pictured above), and two nieces. They work together to operate a laundry business and earn $6 US each day. They have seen their business grow and would like to expand to accommodate their increased customer base. They have asked for a loan of $1000 US both to purchase a new laundry machine and to renovate their home. A new laundry machine typically costs $600 US and they will use the leftover money to do some home repairs and improvements. They see this investment as an opportunity to increase their daily income and to improve their standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase a laundry machine and to renovate his home.

loans.name: Say

texts.en:
Say H., 43, is a mother of six children and resides with her husband in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She is a farmer and also a vendor selling a variety of vegetables in a busy market. She can make $5 US each day. Her husband, Tim An, 42, has two different businesses to support the family. In the rainy season, he is a fisherman and sometimes he works as a motor taxi driver to earn extra money. His combined income from these two businesses is about $1.50 US each day.

Mrs. Say wants a loan to help her add more foodstuffs to sell, such as fermented fish. She hopes that this will make her business grow.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs for her inventory.

loans.name: Nay

texts.en: Nay Y., 55, lives in Phnom Penh with her husband (pictured above) and four children, working as a farmer. She typically makes $3 US each day and her husband makes $3 US as well, raising pigs and fish. Their children are also able to help support the family through their work as a motortaxi driver, a garment factory worker, a construction worker, and as a waitress. Inflation has been very high in Cambodia over the past year and it has affected food prices and the costs of other basic necessities. Farming has also been very difficult, because of inconsistent weather patterns. Nay Y. has asked for a loan of $1200 US to build a shelter for the animals and also to purchase some feed. She believes this investment will allow her to increase her family’s daily income and also to improve her standard of living.

loans.use: To build a shelter for animals.

loans.name: Tinh

texts.en: Tinh R., 55, lives in Phnom Penh with her husband and four of her children. She is a tailor who is able to make $2.50 US each day and her husband, Kong Thou, makes around $4 US each day as a farmer. The family is also supported through their children's work in the garment factories, in construction, and in the tailoring business. She has asked for a loan of $1000 US to expand her tailoring business through the purchase of silk to make clothes. This investment will allow her to increase her daily production and also her income. She would also like to use some of the money to purchase construction tools for her son. Without the proper tools, he lacks the ability to compete for customers with his construction business.

loans.use: To purchase silk and construction tools.

loans.name: Sim

texts.en: Sim L., 36, lives in Phnom Penh with her husband and two young children. She works as a farmer, together with her husband, Dul Saren, and they are able to make $4 US each day. Inflation has been very high in Cambodia over the past year and it has affected food prices and the costs of other basic necessities. Farming has also been very difficult, because of inconsistent weather patterns. Sim L. has asked for a loan of $1000 US to purchase rice seed, vegetables, and fertilizer. These purchases will allow her to increase her production and increase her daily income. It will also allow her family to improve its standard of living through an increased income.

loans.use: To purchase rice seed, vegetables, and fertilizer.

loans.name: Sotheary Khat Group

texts.en:
Mrs Sotheary K. is the group leader of four in Trok Kandal Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. She is a housewife and a farmer. Mrs Sotheary K.’s field is now infertile, so she decided to ask for a loan to purchase fertilizers to spread in her rice field in order to produce a better and more abundant crop. Her husband, Mr Sotha Soam, is a palm juice collector and subsistence farmer. Mrs Sotheary K. is 36 and the mother of four children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while another one is enrolled in school. The remaining two are staying at home because they are too young to work or study.

Mrs K. will share this loan with the other members of her group. Mr Ky P. did not come to take the loan, but his wife came instead of him so she is presented in the photo.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers to spread in her rice field in order to produce a better and more abundant crop.

loans.name: Eal

texts.en: Mrs. Eal N. is 32 years old and lives with her husband Kub Matt in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. To help support their three children and their education expenses, she sells fish in the market and he works in construction. Mrs. Eal has been renting her stall in the market since 2007 and is now applying for a loan in order to purchase this stall. This will eliminate her current monthly rental costs. By reducing her business overhead, Mrs. Eal hopes that she will be able to focus on increasing her business inventory to include vegetables, pork, and beef.

loans.use: To purchase the stall she rents in the market

loans.name: Mak

texts.en: Mrs. Mak M. is a widow who lives in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. She works out of her home as a tailor, and can generate up to $15 US in revenue daily. She has six children, three of whom are married. Her oldest son lives in the United States, and her two other sons work as goldsmiths in Cambodia. Mrs. Mak is requesting a loan of $1,200 US so that she can purchase cloth for her business. The remaining money would be applied towards repairing her motorbike, which is her family's main source of transportation.

loans.use: To purchase additional cloth for her tailoring business and to repair a motorbike.

loans.name: Ke

texts.en:
Mr. Ke S. is a 36-year-old boat driver who lives in Phnom Penh. His wife, Le Hongfeu is 34 and sells groceries from home. Together, the couple can generate up to $25 each day in revenue to help support their three children, all of whom are students.

Mr. Ke is applying for a loan of $1000. He would like to use $500 to purchase more groceries for his wife's business. With the remaining $500 he would like to invest towards opening a new business and start a fish-selling stand.

Becasue Mr. Ke was unavailable when we visited, his wife is pictured above.

CREDIT MFI is an independent Cambodian faith-based organization. It aims to empower the economically active poor and small entrepreneurs by providing inclusive financial services throughout both rural and urban communities in Cambodia.

loans.use: Half to purchase more groceries for his wife's business, and half to open another stand to sell fish.

loans.name: Rose Kirungi, Kisakye Group

texts.en: Rose K. has a retail shop business in Rubaga that she has been running for a long time. She is married with children and she has been our client as a member of Kisakye Women’s Group in Rubaga. She and Fatumah N., Catherine M., Agnes N., and Betty K. would like a loan to help them improve their businesses. Rose would like to buy more goods for her shop like sugar, cooking oil, soap, rice, maize flour, and so on using her part of the loan. Her dream is to transform this same shop into a wholesale shop once she gets start-up capital.

loans.use: Rose Kirungi would like to buy more goods for her shop like sugar, cooking oil, soap, rice, and maize flour

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Pearl Microfinance Limited - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Tahmina

texts.ru:
Tahmina V. lives in Dushanbe. She is a saleswoman in the Sadvarg shopping center. She has been selling women’s clothing for almost five years. She is married and has two children. Her husband is unemployed, so she and her business are the family's sole source of income. She would like to import women's underclothing, so she turned to us for a loan. She will pay back the loan over 12 months. This will help her increase sales volume and widen her range of goods.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer.

Васиева Тахмина проживает в городе Душанбе. Занимается торговлей в центральном торговом центре «Садбарг». Торгует уже почти пять лет женской одеждой. Она замужем и имеет двоих детей. Муж нигде не работает , поэтому она и ее бизнес является основным источником доходов. Хочет привезти нижнее белье для женщин и поэтому обратилась к нам за кредитом.Погасить кредит планирует в течении 12 месяцев.Это поможет ей увеличить товарооборот и пополнить ассортимент товаров.

loans.use: Sales

loans.name: Faizigul

texts.ru:
Faizigul M. produces and sells cultured dairy products. From milk bought from the area's residents she makes kefir, cottage cheese, sour cream, etc. In order to diversify, she decided to buy a separator for cream production. This will help her attract new clients and increase profit. She decided to take out a loan for purchase of the desired equipment, and she will pay back the loan over 10 months. Her business will help provide her family with dairy products, and also lend financial support to her husband. She has five children, and providing for them is not easy at this point.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer.

Муродова Файзигуль занимается производством и продажей кило-молочной продукции. Скупает молоко у населения и производит кефир , творог , сметану и т.д.Для того , чтобы разнообразить ассортимент продуктов она решила купить сепаратор для производства сливок. Это поможет ей привлечь новых клиентов и увеличить доходы. Чтобы купить желаемый аппарат Планирует получить кредит со сроком в 10 месяцев. Ее бизнес помогает обеспечивать семью молочными продуктами , а так же дает финансовую поддержку для ее мужа. У нее пятеро детей , обеспечить которых не так просто в данный момент.

loans.use: Purchase of a separator

loans.name: Gulchehra

texts.ru:
Gulchehra U. lives in the Abdurahmon Jomi district. She is 36 years old, married, and has two children. She is a housewife, but also practices agriculture. She has a plot of land where she grows a variety of crops. Now is the corn planting season, so she needs to buy fertilizer and seeds. To do this she decided to take out a loan, to be repaid over 6 months. This will help her earn money and help her husband.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer.

Умарова Гульчехра жительница района Абдурахмони Джоми.Возраст 36 лет , замужем и имеет двоих детей. Домохозяйка , но занимается земледелием.Имеет участок земли , которую засеивает различными культурами. Сейчас сезон посева кукурузы , поэтому для посева ей необходимо закупить семена и удобрения. Для этого она запланировала получить кредит и погасить его в течении 6 месяцев.Эта деятельность помогает ей зарабатывать деньги и помогать мужу .

loans.use: Purchase of fertilizer and corn seeds

loans.name: Aminata

texts.fr:
Aminata Kanouté is a married woman who lives in Thies’s Randoulène neighborhood. She has 28 years' experience in her main business of selling seasonal fruit. With this loan she would like to increase her revenue by buying large quantities of mangoes to retail at the local market.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer.

aminata kanouté est une femme mariée qui habite au quartier randoulène de THIES.elle bénéficie d'une expérience de 28 ans dans son activité principale de vente de fruits de saison.avec ce pret elle veut améliorer son chiffre d'affaire en achetant des mangues en quantité pour les revendre au détail sur le marché local.

loans.use: To buy and sell seasonal fruit

loans.name: Saer

texts.fr:
Mr N. is a young man living in Thies. He is a member of UIMCEC’s Jammy Xaléyi fund in Thies. His main business is metalwork, which he has been doing for over a decade. With the sum he is requesting, he wants to buy raw materials so that he can meet his delivery deadlines.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer.

mr N. est un jeune homme qui vit à THIES .c'est un sociétaire de la caisse de jammy xaléyi de UIMCEC DE THIES .sa principale activité c'est la tolerie qu'il pratique depuis une dizaine d'année .avec somme qu'il demande il veut acheter des matières premières afin de respecter ses délais de livraison.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for metalwork

loans.name: Malado

texts.fr:
Malado is a married woman who runs a business in the town of Thies. She has been selling a variety of products consisting of quality fabrics, and fashionable shoes and handbags for 8 years. Her primary customers are women of her generation and young girls. She would like a loan to build up her inventory.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer.

malado est une femme mariée qui fait du commerce dans la ville de thies.elle vend des produits diversifiés constitués de tissus de qualité ;des chaussures et des sacs de mode depuis 8 ans.sa principale clientèle est constituée par lers femmes de sa génération et les jeunes filles .elle veut un pret pour renforcer son stock de marchandises.

loans.use: Business selling all types of fabric and fashionable shoes

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en: Hawa W. is a 23-year-old young woman. She is married with 2 children who are currently in school. She is a very hardworking and resourceful wife and mother. She is a retailer of charcoal in her neighborhood. Charcoal is a very popular source of energy for cooking in almost all the traditional Ghanaian homes. Hawa obtains her supply of charcoal from the surrounding villages of Obuasi and retails it to her customers. She wants to use the loan to buy bulk supplies of charcoal to retail to her customers. She hopes to use part of her profit to pay her children’s educational fees. She belongs to the community group called King of Kings Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as a form of social collateral to access loans and provide peer pressure to repay the loans.

loans.use: To buy bulk supplies of charcoal

loans.name: Abena

texts.en: Abena K. is a divorced woman with 3 children who are currently in school. She is a 45-year-old trader who trades in charcoal. Charcoal is a very popular source of energy for cooking in many traditional Ghanaian homes. Through this business, she has supported her first born to complete senior high school. Abena obtains her supply of charcoal from the surrounding villages of Obuasi and retails it to her customers. She wants to use the loan to buy more supplies of charcoal to increase her stock. She belongs to the community group called King of Kings Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as a form of social collateral to access loans and provide peer pressure to repay the loans.

loans.use: To buy more supplies of charcoal

loans.name: Shallot

texts.en: Shallot A. is 39 years old. She is a widow and the mother of 3 children. She lost her husband through a motor accident 6 years ago. She works harder than ever since her responsibility increased as a single parent. She sells pork and meat pies in Obuasi Market. Pork is used to prepare all kinds of local dishes like fufu, banku, and palava sauce. It is one of the most popular meats enjoyed by many Ghanaian traditional homes. She buys in bulk and retails to her customers at a profit. She wants to use the loan to buy more pork, flour, and oil in bulk for her meat pies. She believes this will provide her with adequate income to finance her children’s education. She belongs to the community group called Nyame Bekyere (meaning "God will provide") Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as a form of social collateral to access loans and provide peer pressure to repay the loans.

loans.use: To buy more pork, flour, and oil in bulk for her meat pies

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama is a 45-year-old mother of 4 children. Ten years ago, Ama decided to sell charcoal at the Obuasi market. Since then, she has become one of the most popular charcoal sellers at the market. She has good customer relationships, which make customers enjoy buying from her all the time. Charcoal still remains the most popular source of energy for cooking in many traditional Ghanaian homes.

Ama will be using the loan to purchase charcoal in bulk and retail it to her customers for a profit. This, she believes, will decrease her costs significantly to enable her to raise a good income to support her children in school. She is a member of the community group called The Lord Is My Shepherd Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as a form of social collateral to access loans and provide peer pressure to repay the loans.

loans.use: To purchase charcoal in bulk

loans.name: Akua

texts.en:
Akua, 50 years old, is married with 9 children. For the past 20 years, she has been selling kenkey in her neighborhood. This has given her a rich experience in kenkey production and sales with many customers. As a resourceful mother, she supported 4 children who graduated from senior high school and started university education. Kenkey, a very popular Ghanaian dish, is prepared from milled maize grains, cooked, and eaten with hot pepper and fried fish.

Akua will be using the loan to purchase maize, vegetable oil, vegetables, and firewood, which are the major raw materials, in bulk. This will help reduce her costs very significantly to enable her to raise more income to support her children’s education. She is a member of the community group called Blessing Trust group. The group guarantees loans through a repayment pledge. Peer pressure and support provide the incentive to repay; if one person in the group defaults, the group members make up the repayment amount. Akua's photograph was taken during her group meeting.

loans.use: To purchase maize, vegetable oil, vegetables, and firewood, which are the major raw materials, in bulk

loans.name: Juana

texts.es:
Juana is a hard working, single mother of humble origin. She has raised her family and the children who are still under her care by selling hardware at the 16 D. Julio market on Thursdays and Sundays.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

Es una persona muy trabajadora, madre sola, D. clase muy humilD. saca adelante a su familia, y los hijos que tiene aun a su cargo, vendiendo articulos D. ferreteria en la feria 16 D. julio los jueves y domingo,

loans.use: Purchase hardware

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en: Theresa, 32 years old, is married with no children. Her inability to have children has a medical reason. However, she takes care of 2 of her sister's kids. She is a trader who trades in garment clothes and polyesters, women's slippers, and dressing bags. She normally buys her supplies on credit and pays back when the goods are sold. She is however convinced that her business can grow better with increased working capital. She wants to use the loan to purchase bulk amounts of garment clothes, slippers, and dressing bags to enable her to reduce her cost to raise a good income. She hopes to use part of her profit to get a decent shelter for her family in the future. She is a member of the community group called Blessing Trust group. The group guarantees loans through a repayment pledge. Peer pressure and support provide the incentive to repay; if one person in the group defaults, the group members make up the repayment amount. Theresa's photograph was taken at her group meeting. She is the one with the red handkerchief.

loans.use: To purchase bulk amounts of garment clothes, slippers, and dressing bags

loans.name: Marta Angelica

texts.es:
Marta Angelica lives in the county of San Jose Villa Nueva in the department of La Libertad. Her nuclear family is maD. up of her husband and 2 kids who are studying at college.

For many years she has been getting credit through Integral, and these loans have helped her to improve her shop and start her business selling typical foods which she runs with the help of her family. She now wants to dedicate some time to home improvements, especially to repairing the roof and whitewashing and repairing the walls as it is now winter and they get a lot of leaks which can be problematic. This is why she is asking for a loan; so that she can solve the problems that her house incurs each winter.

Translated from Spanish by Liz Harvey, Kiva Volunteer

Doña Marta Angélica, vive en el Municipio D. San José Villa Nueva, ubicado en el Departamento D. La Libertad. Su núcleo familiar esta integrado por su esposo y dos hijas las cuales se encuentran estudiando en la Universidad. DesD. hace muchos años ha adquirido créditos con Integral, los cuales le han ayudado a ir mejorando la tienda e iniciar en el negocio D. venta D. comida típica que administra con la ayuda D. su familia. Hoy quiere dedicar parte D. sus esfuerzos para mejorar su casa dándole prioridad al cambio D. techo, repellos y afinados en paredes, ya que en el invierno sufre D. filtraciones a su vivienda que le generan problemas D. habitabilidad. Por ello se encuentra solicitando un préstamo, que le permita solventar esos problemas que le aquejan en cada invierno que pasa.

loans.use: To repair the roof and whitewash the walls/PARA REPARACIÓN DE TECHO, REPELLO Y AFINADO DE PAREDES EN LA VIVIENDA.

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en:
Hannah M., 52 years old, is married with 6 children. She is a very experienced mother who demonstrates motherhood with a sense of responsibility. For the past 15 years, she has been selling kenkey locally. As a responsible mother, she supported 3 children who graduated from teacher training college and then started working. Kenkey is a favorite food for many Ghanaians. It is tasty and so satisfying. It is prepared from milled maize grains, cooked, and eaten with hot pepper and fried fish.

Hannah will be using the loan to purchase raw materials, such as maize, vegetable oil, vegetables, and firewood, in bulk. This will help her to avoid constant price hikes resulting from the current food crisis in the country. She is a member of the community group called Blessing Trust group. The group guarantees loans through a repayment pledge. Peer pressure and support provide the incentive to repay, and if one person in the group defaults, the group members make up the repayment amount. Hannah's photograph was taken at her group meeting.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials, such as maize, vegetable oil, vegetables, and firewood, in bulk

loans.name: Akosua

texts.en: Akosua is 37 and has been operating a grocery shop for the past 20 years. She is married with a single child, who is currently in school. Her experience in trading has made her one of the most successful traders. She sells items like rice, sugar, vegetable oil, bottled water, body and hair creams, skimmed powdered milk, etc. She deems it a big opportunity to expand her business to include other items frequently demanded by customers. She wants to use the loan to buy more bags of rice, bags of sugar, cartons of vegetable oil, boxes of body and hair creams, etc to increase her stock of goods available for sale. Akosua belongs to the community group called Blessing Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as a form of social collateral to access loans and provide peer pressure to repay the loans. Akosua's photograph was taken during her group meeting. She is the one in green apparel.

loans.use: To buy more bags of rice, bags of sugar, cartons of vegetable oil, boxes of body and hair creams, etc

loans.name: Sergey

texts.en:
Sergey is married, and he has a 9-year-old son. He and his family live in Stryi. For the past 4 years, Sergey has been in the business of offering transportation services all over Europe. Currently, he has one employee working for him, and his net profit is approximately 3,200 Grivnas (i.e., over $600) per month.

Sergey is seeking a loan in the amount of 4,000 Grivnas ($875) to purchase two new tires for his vehicle, which will help him meet all the standard customs' requirements when he crosses the border in his car. With the loan proceeds, he is hoping to generate additional profit and to eventually purchase a second vehicle for his business. Moreover, the expected additional income will help Sergey pay for certain medical expenses he incurred when his son had surgery to have a tumor removed from his leg.

loans.use: To purchase two new tires for his business' vehicle and to eventually purchase a second vehicle

loans.name: Ganna

texts.en:
Ganna is retired, yet she continues to work as a small entrepreneur in one of the busiest open markets in Zaporozhye. Ganna has been selling household chemicals for the past 10 years. She launched this venture to provide for her everyday needs because her retirement income was insufficient for her to survive. Recently, her business has grown a great deal, and Ganna now has over $3,500 in inventory.

Ganna is requesting a loan in the amount of 5,000 Grivnas ($1,075) to diversify her product line. More specifically, she is planning to purchase additional merchandise, such as cleaning liquids and powders, polishes, drain cleaners, shampoos, disinfectants, air fresheners, and laundry products, in order to attract more customers and to thereby increase her business' sales. She firmly believes that increased funding will facilitate her business' ongoing success and will allow her to continue to improve the quality of life for her family.

loans.use: To diversify her product line by purchasing additional inventory to thereby attract more customers

loans.name: Ludmila

texts.en:
Ludmila is an entrepreneur from Zaporozhye. She works in one of the local markets, known as Yubileiniy, where she sells men’s shirts. She has two vending facilities, and her daughter is helping her with sales in one of the vending facilities. Ludmila has been in this trade for 10 years. Currently, she has about $3,600 in inventory.

Ludmila is currently seeking a loan in the amount of 5,000 Grivnas ($1,075). She plans to use the loan proceeds to increase her assortment of shirts and to expand her business. With the expected increase in sales and profits from this loan, Ludmila hopes to open additional vending kiosks and to thereby improve her family's standard of living.

loans.use: To expand her business by increasing her turnover capital and, eventually, to open additional vending kiosks

loans.name: Oleg

texts.en:
Oleg is married to a wonderful lady, Lesya, and he has two beautiful kids, Bogdan and Natalya. The family of four lives in Drogobych, a picturesque resort area of Western Ukraine. Oleg understands that, as the head of the family, the burden is on him to work hard in order to provide for his family and their basic needs. He sells sports inventory, which is always in high demand in this famous mountain and ski resort area. Oleg’s business is characterized by certified quality products, reasonable prices, and a whole network of small vending locations in the region.

Oleg remembers how miserable the situation in the sports inventory market was after the collapse of the Soviet Union. Fortunately, a new wave of interest in sports came about in 2000. Around that time, Oleg opened his first sporting goods store, which he named “Planeta Sportu” (“Sport Planet”). Currently, he has about $6,000 in inventory, and his gross income is over $1,500. Oleg has two profitable vending locations in two different towns: Drogobych and Truskavets. Moreover, he is planning to open a third vending location in the town of Stryi. Therefore, Oleg is seeking a loan to purchase quality stands for his new store so that he can have a nice arrangement of merchandise, which he believes would be another boon to his business.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise stands to be used at a new vending location

loans.name: Irma Yolanda

texts.es:
For more than ten years, Irma Yolanda has dedicated herself to raising chickens at her house. She buys them when they are small, feeds them, then sells them either from her home or at the San Martín Jilotepeque market.

Thanks to her business, she has prospered. She also works as a primary school teacher in a village of San Martín Jilotepeque.

She wants to buy more chickens and take advantage of the busy commercial seasons in her locality.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

Irma Yolanda desde hace mas de 10 años se dedica a la crianza de pollos en su casa. Ella los compra pequeños, los alimenta y después los vende en su casa, en el mercado de la localidad de San Martín Jilotepeque, y algunas personas la buscan en su casa. Gracias a su negocio, ella ha prosperado y además trabaja como maestra de educación primaria en la escuela de una aldea de San Martín Jilotepeque. Ella quiere comprar más pollos y aprovechar las temporadas de negocio en la localidad.

loans.use: Raising chickens.

loans.name: Erasmo Gonzalo

texts.es:
Mr. Erasmo Gonzalo T. G. has a small carpentry workshop in the village of Sacala de las Lomas, located in the San Martin Jilotepeque municipality. For more than three years he has dedicated himself to making traditional crafts out of wood, which he sells from his house or on order.

Erasmo Gonzalo is married, and his wife works as a nurse. They have two children and, thanks to his business, he is getting ahead. He is seeking a loan because he needs to buy more raw materials given that the price of lumber has increased substantially.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

El señor Erasmo Gonzalo T. G., tiene una pequeña carpintería en la aldea Sacala de las Lomas, municipio de San Martin Jilotepeque. Desde hace mas de tres años se dedica a fabricar artesanías típicas en madera, las cuales vende en su casa y algunas organizaciones le hacen pedidos. Erasmo Gonzalo es casado, su esposa trabaja como enfermera, tiene 2 hijos, y gracias a su empresa y negocio el esta saliendo adelante. Su préstamo es porque El necesita comprar más materia prima, ya que la madera ha subido mucho de precio.

loans.use: Purchase wood to make furniture.

loans.name: Matowéna

texts.fr:
Born February 11th, 1973 in Assoamakokji in the Sotouboua prefecture, Ms. Matowéna W. is single and has one child. She is a retailer and has established a restaurant called “La Savoureuse” where she serves meals of grilled fish in Lomé’s Avédzi neighborhood. She began this business in 2001 and hasn’t yet borrowed money from WAGES. Her restaurant receives many customers and she would like to provide them with quality service. To this end she is seeking a loan of 300,000 Francs CFA to buy 12 cases of fresh fish.

Translated from French by Liana Bianchi, Kiva Volunteer

Née le 11 février 1973 à Assoamakodji dans la préfecture de Sotouboua, Mademoiselle W. Matowéna est célibataire avec un enfant. Elle est revendeuse et a crée le restaurant la SAVOUREUSE où elle fait la restauration de poissons braisés dans le quartier Avédzi à Lomé. Elle a commencé cette activité en 2001 et n’a pas encore bénéficié du crédit auprès de WAGES. Son restaurant accueille beaucoup de client et elle désire leur rendre un service de qualité. A cet effet elle sollicite un crédit de 300.000FCFA pour acheter 12 cartons de poissons frais

loans.use: Purchase 12 cases of fresh fish

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for WAGES - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Dora Wilma

texts.es:
Dora is hardworking and responsible person of humble origin who sells clothing at the 16 de Julio market. Her husband is in Brazil, so she is raising her two children, with another one on the way.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

Es una persona Humilde de clase sencilla vende en la feria 16 de julio, su esposo esta en el brasil, ella saca adelante a dos hijos y uno por nacer, es muy esforzada, muy responasable

loans.use: Purchase this season’s apparel

payments.comment: Correction due to underpayment for business 54082

loans.name: Balbina

texts.es:
Mrs. Balvina L. has a business selling basic consumer goods from a stand at the local market. She sells on Thursdays and Sundays, as these are the main selling days at the market.

She inherited the business from her mother, and has now had it for more than fifteen years.

Mrs. L. has ten children and, thanks to her business, she has been able to provide an education for all of them. Her goal is to help them to get ahead, and that they complete their studies and become professionals.

Her husband works in construction, and helps her support their home economically.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Balvina L. tiene un negocio de venta de productos de consumo diario, y cuenta con un puesto en el mercado de la localidad. Ella vende los días jueves y domingo de la semana, por ser los días principales de venta en el mercado. Su negocio lo heredo de su madre, y tiene más de 15 años de tenerlo. La señora L. tiene 10 hijos, y gracias a su negocio les ha dado estudio a todos ellos, su meta es sacarlos adelante y que completen sus estudios hasta llegar a ser profesionales. Su esposo trabaja en la construcción y le ayuda al sostenimiento económico de su hogar.

loans.use: Purchase basic consumer products to offer for sale.

loans.name: Kossiwa

texts.fr:
Born in 1973 in Atakpamé, a town located 145 kilometers from Lomé, Mrs. Kossiwa M. lives with her husband Koffi YAKOUBA who is a taxi driver. She has two children and does business in grains such as corn and millet, as well as beans. The business that she began in 2004 brings her income that she uses to help her husband with the family’s expenses. She has already benefited from a loan that she successfully repaid. The second loan she is seeking will allow her to buy two bags of corn and two bags of beans to increase her stock and improve sales.

Translated from French by Liana Bianchi, Kiva Volunteer

Née en 1973 à Atakpamé, ville située à 145 Km de Lomé, Madame M. Kossiwa vit avec son mari YAKOUBA Koffi qui est un chauffeur de taxis. Elle a 2 enfants et fait le commerce de céréales tels que le maïs, le mil et du haricot. Cette activité qu’elle a commencée depuis l’année 2004 lui procure de revenu et elle puise de ce revenu pour aider son mari dans les dépenses de la famille. Elle a une fois bénéficié du crédit et a bien remboursé. Ce second crédit qu’elle sollicite lui permettra d’acheter 2 sacs de maïs et 2 sacs du haricot afin d’augmenter son stock et de pouvoir bien vendre.

loans.use: Purchase corn and beans

loans.name: Gloria Catalina

texts.es:
Mrs. Gloria M. L. has had a business raising chickens and pigs for more than six years. She maintains the business at her house.

In addition to tending to and feeding her animals, she also knits traditional crafts in her spare time.

She currently has two children, and is expecting another shortly. Her husband is not in Guatemala and, thanks to her enterprise, her and her children have been able to get ahead.

The loan will be used to purchase more chickens and pigs, which she buys while still small, then sell them from her house and at the local market.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Gloria M. L. tiene un negocio de crianza de pollos y marranos desde hace mas de 6 años, este negocio lo tiene en su casa. Ella además de alimentar y cuidar a los pollos y marranos, también hace tejidos típicos a mano en sus tiempos libres. Actualmente tiene 2 hijos y otro que nacerá próximamente. Su esposo no esta en Guatemala, y gracias a sus negocios ella ha salido adelante con sus hijos. El préstamo lo utilizara para la compra de mas pollos y marranos, los que compra pequeños, y después los vende en su casa y en el mercado de la localidad.

loans.use: Purchase chickens and pigs to raise and sell.

loans.name: Maria Salome

texts.es:
Mrs. Maria Salome Balan has a business selling basic consumer goods from her house. She started the business four years ago.

The idea for her enterprise stemmed from the fact that there is a school next to her home. She takes advantage of being able to sell her products to the boys and girls that attend said school, in addition to neighbors who also buy her merchandise.

This business has been a great help to her and her five children. Her husband works in construction and farming.

She will use her loan to obtain more products for her store.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Maria Salome Balan, tiene un negocio de productos de consumo diario en su casa, este negocio ella lo inicio hace 4 años. La idea de su negocio fue, que existe una escuela de niños y niñas a la par de su casa, y ella aprovecha a vender sus productos con los niños y niñas de dicha escuela, así como personas vecinas que le compran también sus productos. Este negocio ha sido de gran ayuda para ella para ella y sus hijos, tiene 5 hijos. Su esposo trabaja en la industria de la construcción y agricultura. Su préstamo lo utilizara para tener más productos en su tienda.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise for her store.

loans.name: Papa Abdoulaye

texts.fr:
Papa Abdoulaye Dème is a tailor at the big market in Thiès. He has been working in this profession for more than 7 years. He lives in Mbour, is married and father of 3 children. This is his 3rd loan and he is requesting it in order to satisfy the demands of his clients.

Translated from French by Ivana Kostic, Kiva Volunteer.

Papa Abdoulaye Dème est un tailleur sis au marché grand thiès. Il excerce ce métier depuis plus de 7ans. Habitant à Mbour I, il est marié et père de 3 enfants. Il est dans son 3ème prêt et il demande ce prêt pour satisfaire la demande.

loans.use: Purchase of Supplies and Fabrics

loans.name: Ablavi

texts.fr:
Mrs. Ablavi K. was born December 31st, 1964 in Agoè, a neighborhood of Lomé. She grew up in this neighborhood and had two children but is divorced. In 1998 she opened shop selling basic goods, haberdashery items, and jewelry. In her store “Ets Jesus T’aime,” she welcomes many customers because of the diversity of her merchandise. This is her first time borrowing from WAGES and she is seeking this loan to buy 10 crates of tomatoes, 50 necklaces, and five bolts of poplin fabric.

Translated from French by Liana Bianchi, Kiva Volunteer

Madame K. Ablavi est née le 31 décembre 1964 à Agoè, l’un des quartiers de Lomé. Elle a grandi dans ce quartier et a eu deux enfants mais est divorcée. Depuis 1998, elle a ouvert un établissement de vente des produits de premières nécessités, de mercerie et de bijoux. Dans son magasin « ETS JESUS T’AIME » elle accueille beaucoup de clients compte tenue de la diversité de ses marchandises. Elle est à son premier crédit auprès de WAGES et sollicite ce prêt pour acheter 10 cartons de boîtes de tomates, 50 colliers et 5 rouleaux de popeline.

loans.use: Retail of basic goods, haberdashery items and jewelry

loans.name: Abdourahmane

texts.fr:
Abdourahmane is a hay merchant in the town of Concord. He is originally from Sanghé and lives the city of Lamy, is married and a father of 5 children. With the end of the crop season, he wants to build his stock of hay since his main income is drawn from this commercial activity. This is his second loan and he is a loyal client of the mutual funds company.

Translated from French by Ivana Kostic, Kiva Volunteer.

Abdourahmane est un commerçant de foin à Concorde. Il est originaire de Sanghé et habite à cité lamy, il est marié et père de 5 enfants. Avec l'hivernage il veut accroitre son stock car ses principaux revenus sont tirés de son activité commercial.Il est à son 2ème prêt et un fidèle client de la mutuelle.

loans.use: Purchase and selling of hay

loans.name: Balbina

texts.es:
For the past twenty years, Mrs. Balvina E. has had a business raising chickens and pigs at her house.

She sells them both from her home and at the local market.

She has nine children who help her tend to the animals. In her free time, she knits traditional crafts.

Her husband is not in Guatemala.

Thanks to the business she can support her children, and the majority of them are studying.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Balvina E. tiene un negocio de crianza de pollos y marranos en su casa. Su negocio lo tiene desde hace más de 20 años, y vende los pollos y marranos en su casa y en el mercado de la localidad. Tiene 9 hijos, y ellos le ayudan en el cuidado de los animales, en sus tiempos libres se dedica a hacer tejidos típicos a mano. Su esposo no esta en Guatemala. Gracias a este negocio ella mantiene a sus hijos, y la mayoría de ellos están estudiando.

loans.use: Purchase of chickens and pigs to raise and sell.

loans.name: Movimiento De Mujeres Amistad Group

texts.en:
Monise I. Pierre is a young and ambitious Dominican women who came to Esperanza with a dream and a plan to accomplish her vision. A single woman at age 22, Monise finds her inspiration for day-to-day activities fueled by her dream of one day becoming a doctor. Right now, she travels each Thursday to the nearby city of Santiago to buy shirts, pants, skirts, and blouses to sell in the streets of her local community, Amistad, which means friendship. Monise plans to continue selling clothes in the afternoon while she attends school in the mornings.

Monise I. is just one member of the 15-person micro-bank, Movimiento Mujeres de Amistad, which means Women's Movement for Friendship. Each of these unique Dominican entrepreneurs unite in solidarity, allowing them to access funding that they would otherwise never be able to receive on their own. The concept of this group bank paying their loan together is to reduce the risk of one person defaulting, as the others members gladly help cover one another’s payments in order to receive their next loan together. Many of the women in this bank have businesses similar to Monise’s, selling clothing in the streets, while several others sell vegetables in the street, and some even maintain a personal hair salon.

On behalf of Monise, the Movimiento Group Bank, and the entire team here at Esperanza International, we thank you for your support and awareness of the global issue of poverty, in which your efforts are helping to make a difference.

loans.use: To purchase shoes, shirts, skirts, pants, and undergarments

loans.name: Astou

texts.fr:
Mother Astou B., as most people call her, is a merchant of various products that she sells in front of her home located in Keur Massamba Gueye Peulh. She also manages a very big family as she is married and a mother of 7 children. This is her 10th loan with U-IMCEC since she has been a member of the mutual funds company since 2001.
